intro: Trifolium × joachinii, commonly known as the hybrid white clover, is a perennial legume native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its trifoliate leaves, which consist of three oval-shaped leaflets arranged on a central stem. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from late spring to early summer. Trifolium × joachinii is often found in disturbed soils and is used as a forage crop due to its high nutritional value. It has a shallow root system that helps prevent soil erosion and improves soil fertility through nitrogen fixation.
